form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Blumenthal (for himself, Mr. Murphy, and Mr. Lautenberg) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To appropriately restrict sales of ammunition.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Ammunition Background Check Act of 2013 .

paragraph.text: Under current Federal law, it is illegal to sell firearms or ammunition to certain individuals, including felons, fugitives, drug addicts, and those deemed mentally defective or committed to a mental institution.
There is no requirement under Federal law that sellers of ammunition conduct a background check to determine whether potential purchasers are in fact prohibited by law from buying ammunition.

By contrast, under current Federal law, licensed sellers of firearms are required by law to conduct an instant background check using the National Instant Criminal Background Check System of the Justice Department.

Over the last decade, there have been over 100,000,000 background checks conducted under the National Instant Criminal Background Check System with respect to firearms sales, resulting in the blocking of more than 1,500,000 sales of firearms to felons, fugitives, drug addicts, and the mentally ill, among others.
The vast majority of instant background checks on firearms purchases occur in an average of 30 seconds, at minimal inconvenience to firearms sellers and law-abiding purchasers.
The requirement of background checks for ammunition purchases would pose a minimal inconvenience to ammunition sellers and law-abiding purchasers, and would help reduce gun-related violence.

Current Federal law includes a variety of other provisions regulating the sale of firearms, including limits on interstate gun sales and recordkeeping requirements designed to assist in criminal investigations, that do not apply to sales of ammunition.
Sales of ammunition should be held to similar requirements as sales of firearms.

subsection.header: Requiring background checks for purchases of ammunition

paragraph.text: Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by inserting after subsection (u) the following:

On and after the date that is 180 days after the date of enactment of the
Ammunition Background Check Act of 2013 , no person who is licensed under this chapter shall transfer ammunition to any other person who is not licensed under this chapter, unless—

subparagraph.text: before the completion of the transfer, the licensee contacts the national instant criminal background check system established under section 103 of the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act;

clause.text: the system provides the licensee with a unique identification number; or

3 business days (meaning a day on which State offices are open) have elapsed since the licensee contacted the system, and the system has not notified the licensee that the receipt of a firearm by such other person would violate subsection (g) or (n) of this section; and

subparagraph.text: the transferor has verified the identity of the transferee by examining a valid identification document (as defined in section 1028(d) of this title) of the transferee containing a photograph of the transferee.

paragraph.text: If receipt of ammunition would not violate subsection (g) or (n) or State law, the system shall—

subparagraph.text: assign a unique identification number to the transfer;
provide the licensee with the number; and

destroy all records of the system with respect to the call (other than the identifying number and the date the number was assigned) and all records of the system relating to the person or the transfer.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) shall not apply to an ammunition transfer between a licensee and another person if—

clause.text: such other person has presented to the licensee a permit that—

subclause.text: allows such other person to possess or acquire ammunition; and
was issued not more than 5 years earlier by the State in which the transfer is to take place; and

clause.text: the law of the State provides that such a permit is to be issued only after an authorized government official has verified that the information available to such official does not indicate that possession of a firearm or ammunition by such other person would be in violation of law;

subparagraph.text: the Attorney General has approved the transfer under section 5812 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; or
on application of the transferor, the Attorney General has certified that compliance with paragraph (1)(A) is impracticable because—

clause.text: the business premises of the licensee at which the transfer is to occur are extremely remote in relation to the chief law enforcement officer (as defined in subsection (s)(8)); and
there is an absence of telecommunications facilities in the geographical area in which the business premises are located.

paragraph.text: If the national instant criminal background check system notifies any person licensed under this chapter that the information available to the system does not demonstrate that the receipt of ammunition by such other person would violate subsection (g) or (n) or State law, and the licensee transfers ammunition to such other person, the seller shall include in the record of the transfer the unique identification number provided by the system with respect to the transfer.

If any person licensed under this chapter knowingly transfers ammunition to another person and knowingly fails to comply with paragraph (1) of this subsection with respect to the transfer and, at the time such other person most recently proposed the transfer, the national instant criminal background check system was operating and information was available to the system demonstrating that receipt of ammunition by such other person would violate subsection (g) or (n) of this section or State law, the Attorney General may, after notice and opportunity for a hearing, suspend for not more than 6 months or revoke any license issued to the person under section 923, and may impose on the person a civil fine of not more than $5,000 for a first violation, $25,000 for a second violation, and $100,000 for any subsequent violation.

Neither a local government nor an employee of the Federal Government or of any State or local government, responsible for providing information to the national instant criminal background check system shall be liable in an action at law for damages—

subparagraph.text: for failure to prevent the sale or transfer of ammunition to a person whose receipt or possession of the ammunition is unlawful under this section; or
for preventing such a sale or transfer to a person who may lawfully receive or possess ammunition.

paragraph.header: Regulations relating to retention and destruction of records in system
paragraph.text: In promulgating regulations to carry out subsection (v)(2)(C) of section 922 of title 18, United States Code, as added by this Act, the Attorney General shall ensure that the records described in such subsection are destroyed not later than 3 business days after the date on which a licensee is notified that a transfer of ammunition may proceed under such section.

subparagraph.text: Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

clause.text: in subsection (c)—

item.text: by inserting or ammunition after a firearm;

subclause.text: in paragraph (2), by inserting or ammunition after firearm each place it appears.

clause.text: in subsection (d), in the matter following paragraph (9), by adding at the end, the following: Any person who is licensed under this chapter and who sells ammunition to any of the persons described in paragraph (1) through (9) after failing to comply with the requirements of section 922(v) of title 18, United States Code, shall be deemed to have acted knowingly with respect to this subsection..

subparagraph.text: Section 924(a)(5) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking or (t) and inserting , (t), or (v).
Section 103 of the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act (18 U.S.C. 922 note) is amended—

clause.text:
in subsection (i), in the subsection heading, by inserting or ammunition after
firearms ; and
in subsection (j)(2), inserting ammunition, after The terms .

paragraph.text: Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Background checks for ammunition transfers by unlicensed persons

paragraph.text: the term unlicensed transferee means a person who—

subparagraph.text: is not licensed under this chapter; and
desires to received ammunition from an unlicensed transferor; and

paragraph.text: the term unlicensed transferor means a person who—

subparagraph.text: is not licensed under this chapter; and
desires to transfer ammunition to an unlicensed transferee.

paragraph.text: It shall be unlawful for an unlicensed transferee to knowingly transfer ammunition to an unlicensed transferor and knowingly fail to obtain a background check conducted by a licensed dealer in accordance with subsection (d) with respect to the transfer.
An unlicensed transferee who violates paragraph (1) shall be fined under this title, imprisoned for not more than 1 year, or both.

subsection.text: If any unlicensed transferee knowingly transfers ammunition to an unlicensed transferor and knowingly fails to obtain a background check conducted by a licensed dealer in accordance with subsection (d) with respect to the transfer and, at the time such unlicensed transferor most recently proposed the transfer, the national instant criminal background check system was operating and information was available to the system demonstrating that receipt of ammunition by such unlicensed transferor would violate subsection (g) or (n) of section 922 or State law, the Attorney General may, after notice and opportunity for a hearing, impose on the unlicensed transferee a civil fine of not more than $5,000 for a first violation, $25,000 for a second violation, and $100,000 for any subsequent violation.
A licensed dealer who agrees to assist in the transfer of ammunition between an unlicensed transferor and an unlicensed transferee shall—

paragraph.text: record the transfer on a form specified by the Attorney General;

comply with section 922(v) as if transferring the ammunition from the inventory of the licensed dealer to the unlicensed transferee (except that a licensed dealer assisting in the transfer of ammunition under this subsection shall not be required to comply again with the requirements of section 922(v) in delivering the ammunition to the unlicensed transferee) and notify the unlicensed transferor and unlicensed transferee—

subparagraph.text: of such compliance; and

if the transfer is subject to the requirements of section 922(v)(1), of any receipt by the licensed dealer of a notification from the national instant criminal background check system that the transfer would violate section 922 or State law;

paragraph.text: not later than 31 days after the date on which the transfer occurs, submit to the Attorney General a report of the transfer, which—

subparagraph.text: shall be on a form specified by the Attorney General by regulation; and

paragraph.text: if the licensed dealer assists an unlicensed transferor in transferring, at the same time or during any 5 consecutive business days, 1,000 or more rounds of ammunition, to the same unlicensed transferee, in addition to the reports required under paragraph (4), prepare a report of the multiple transfers, which shall—

subparagraph.text: be prepared on a form specified by the Attorney General; and
not later than the close of business on the date on which the transfer requiring the report under this paragraph occurs, be submitted to—

clause.text: the office specified on the form described in subparagraph (A); and

paragraph.text: retain a record of the transfer as part of the permanent business records of the licensed dealer.
The table of sections for chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

toc.toc-entry: 932. Background checks for ammunition transfers by unlicensed persons.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated to the Attorney General such sums as are necessary—

paragraph.text: to ensure that the national instant criminal background check system operates as quickly and effectively as it did before the enactment of this Act; and
for the cost of implementing and enforcing the amendments made by this Act, including audits and other regulatory or enforcement efforts.

subsection.text: Section 922(b)(5) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by striking or armor-piercing ammunition and inserting or ammunition.

subsection.header: No ammunition sales contrary to State law
subsection.text: Section 922(b)(2) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by inserting or ammunition after any firearm; and
by inserting or ammunition after such firearm.
Section 922(b)(3) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: by inserting or ammunition after any firearm; and
by striking rifle or shotgun and inserting ammunition, rifle, or shotgun.

paragraph.text: Section 922(a) is amended—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (3) by inserting or ammunition after firearm each place it appears; and
in paragraph (5), by inserting or ammunition after firearm each place it appears except the last place it appears.

paragraph.text: Section 923(g) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (1)(A)—

clause.text: in the first sentence, by inserting or ammunition after other disposition of firearms; and
in the third sentence, by striking , or any licensed importer or manufacturer of ammunition, and inserting , or any licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer of ammunition,;

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (2)—

clause.text: by inserting or ammunition after disposition of firearms; and
by inserting or ammunition after a firearm;

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (3), by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: Each licensee shall prepare a report of multiple sales or other dispositions whenever the licensee sells or otherwise disposes of, at one time or during any 5 consecutive business days, a large quantity of ammunition (as determined in accordance with clause (ii)) to an unlicensed person. The report shall be prepared on a form specified by the Attorney General and forwarded to the office specified thereon and to the department of State police or State law enforcement agency of the State and, where feasible, the local law enforcement agency of the local jurisdiction in which the sale or other disposition took place, not later than the close of business on the day that the multiple sale or other disposition occurs.
The Attorney General shall determine the quantity of ammunition that constitutes a large quantity for the purpose of this subparagraph, the quantity of which—

subclause.text: may be modified by the Attorney General from time to time; and
may vary by geographic area if the Attorney General determines that it is appropriate to assist law enforcement efforts.

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (6)—

clause.text: by inserting or a significant quantity of ammunition, after theft or loss of a firearm; and

by adding at the end the following: Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of the Ammunition Background Check Act of 2013 , the Attorney General shall promulgate rules defining significant quantity for the purpose of this paragraph.; and

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (7), by inserting or any quantity of ammunition after 1 or more firearms; and

paragraph.text: Section 4182(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to exemptions relating to firearms) is amended by inserting and except as provided in paragraphs (1)(A) and (3)(C) of section 923(g) of title 18, United States Code, before no person holding a Federal license.

subsection.header: Making it a crime To steal ammunition
subsection.text: Section 922(u) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by inserting or ammunition after in firearms; and
by inserting or ammunition after any firearm.

subsection.header: Keeping ammunition out of the hands of juveniles
subsection.text: Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1)(B), by striking only; and
in paragraph (2)(B), by striking only.
Section 923(a) of title 18, United States Code, is amended in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking , or importing or manufacturing and inserting or.
Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended—

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (12), by inserting or ammunition after any firearm; and
in paragraph (13), by inserting or ammunition after firearms.

subsection.text: Section 921(a)(17)(B) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (i), by striking or at the end;
in clause (ii), by striking the period at the end and inserting ; or; and
by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: a bullet or projectile which is coated with Teflon or any chemical compound with properties similar to Teflon.

paragraph.text: Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
The term incendiary ammunition—

subparagraph.text: means a bullet that is designed for the purpose of, held out by the manufacturer or distributor as, or generally recognized as having a specialized capability to ignite upon impact; and
includes such bullets commonly designated as M1 Incendiary, M23 Incendiary, M8 Armor-Piercing Incendiary, API, M20 Armor-Piercing Incendiary Tracer, or APIT.

paragraph.text: Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: by inserting or incendiary ammunition after armor piercing ammunition each place it appears, except—

clause.text: in section 921; and
in section 923(k);

subparagraph.text: in section 922(b)(5), by inserting or incendiary ammunition after armor-piercing ammunition; and
in section 923(k)—

clause.text: by inserting , incendiary projectiles, and after armor piercing projectiles; and
by inserting or incendiary ammunition as defined in section 921(a)(36) before the period at the end.

subsection.text: Section 922(a)(7) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (A)—
in subparagraph (B), by inserting , transfer, or possession after manufacture; and
in subparagraph (C), by inserting , transfer, or possession after manufacture.

subsection.header: Grandfathering of continued possession of ammunition

paragraph.text: The amendments made by this section shall not apply to the possession of any armor piercing ammunition (as defined in section 921(a)(17)(B) of title 18, United States Code, as amended by subsection (a)), or incendiary ammunition (as defined in section 921(a)(36) of title 18, United States Code, as added by subsection (b)) otherwise lawfully possessed under Federal law on the date of enactment of this Act.
Nothing in paragraph (1) shall be construed to authorize the transfer, sale, or delivery of any armor piercing ammunition or incendiary ammunition described in paragraph (1).
